awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying the Interplay of Expertise Development, Creativity, and Learning in University Makerspaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Makerspaces are collaborative and open work environments which are becoming increasingly popular on university campuses. As students work in makerspaces they traverse and integrate a wide variety of skills that create a dynamic relationship between the learning processes, creative exploration, and expertise acquisition. This work provides an initial examination of this interplay between learning and expertise. It begins to answer the question of what and how students learn in university makerspaces. At present, it is unclear what university students actually learn in university makerspaces and how this compares with other hands-on learning opportunities such as competition team projects, undergraduate research, or similar experiences. Educators hope makerspaces are effective learning environments that can 1) enhance lifelong and self-directed learning skills, 2) expand engineering curricula, and 3) motivate while simultaneously educating the next generation of STEM students. However, there are few studies on the development of expertise and learning or their impact on creativity in makerspaces because these spaces are complex, dynamic, non-standard environments that provoke unprecedented challenges when it comes to their study. In addition, most work on expertise and creativity compares novices and experts but fails to create detailed accounts of how one moves from novice to expert nor how this transition influences the ability to be creative within the domain. Most studies of expertise are comparison studies or simply snapshot of groups at certain points in time. These studies overlook the development of expertise. In makerspaces, students are often motivated by an idea to make a creative project, and in turn they thereby develop expertise and undergo learning. This learning that takes place in makerspaces is natural, organic, and uncontrolled. This study of makerspaces will examine these phenomena as they naturally occur, rather than altering the environment to conform to a typical controlled experiment. This approach enables the study of the evolution of making as engineering makers mature and evolve on two different campuses.

This study will focus on two very different makerspaces at two different universities. Both spaces feature many of the commonly found making equipment (e.g., 3D printers, electronics equipment, wood and metal working equipment, etc.), but each has its own unique culture and placement into the programs at their respective universities.  Further, the differences between the universities create a unique opportunity for comparison.  To study the makerspaces at these two universities, the following methodological procedures will be used: 1) ethnographic observation in making activities, and 2) observations and interviews with student groups and individual students who are making in the engineering makerspaces. This work is also envisioned as a springboard for future studies in understanding makerspaces including makerspace culture, barriers and pathways to entry, tensions produced in the space, student design processes, innovative approaches, and collaborative efforts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Universities and colleges continue to invest resources into makerspaces, yet systematic empirical research into the learning that happens through student engagement is limited. This project conducted an in-depth qualitative examination into learning through making. The experiences of students were explored at two universities with different makerspace environments, curricular integrations of making, and engineering programs. The project gave considerable attention to the making experiences of women to better understand their learning through making, identity as makers, and making journeys in what has been cast as a largely masculine endeavor and environment. The data clearly demonstrate the complex and multifaceted types of learning that happen in academic makerspaces, the central role of peer and faculty relationships in students’ making experiences and belonging in makerspaces, and the importance of designing inclusive makerspace environments that redress and debunk myths that making is a masculine endeavor.

Ethnographic observations were conducted of students working within makerspaces as were in-depth phenomenological interviews of makers. At University A, the makerspaces observed were housed primarily in engineering and are deeply integrated into the undergraduate curriculum. At University B, the makerspace is a large making environment open to all students. Ethnographers adopted the role of participant observers and conducted observations of the different makerspaces to understand how students navigated and understood the cultures of making at each university.

Ethnographic observations provide insight into the cultural biases that grease the pathways for some students’ access and success, while simultaneously creating invisible barriers for others. We found that students carry forms of capital – social and cultural resources – that impact their entry and navigation of the culture of makerspaces. Some students enter the university with more “capital” (e.g. prior knowledge and comfort with the language of innovation) than others, setting them up to understand the rules for working in makerspaces. We found that communication plays a central role in shaping makerspace cultures as students (1) moved from outsider to insider; (2) negotiated a culture characterized by tensions of access vs. exclusivity, (3) learned to use the vocabularies of innovation and creativity; and (4) worked collaboratively to cultivate supportive making communities.

To understand students’ making journeys and their learning, thirty-five phenomenologically based interviews were conducted with students who self-identified as makers at both universities. Twenty-five of the 35 interviews were with women makers, seeking to provide a more nuanced understanding to identify ways that educators can broaden participation. While the data found distinctly gendered experiences in women’s making pathways, all interviews served to reveal the modes and contents of learning that happens.

Our interviews with women makers revealed four aspects common among their pathways: (1) early forms of apprenticeship through mentors; (2) overcoming and resisting limiting gendered expectations imposed by others; (3) successful articulations of community grounded in making-centered coursework and personal passions; and (4) relationships in college that expanded access, leadership, and visibility toward fuller participation. The interviews with women showcase how makerspaces create a culture of learning, facilitate students’ design journey, and form a laboratory for creativity.

The interview data were used to construct a typology of learning through making (Figure-Learning in Makerspaces). Comparing learning between the two universities, we found that makers at both universities gain comparable content knowledge, cultural knowledge, and ingenuity, while students at University A gain more self-awareness and learn through relationships more than counterparts at University B. Findings serve to bolster the value of academic makerspaces by identifying concrete forms and contents of learning. Further, the typology of learning through making has wide transferable value for applications to other experiential learning environments

Importantly, our findings clearly indicate that all students’ experiences in makerspaces are not equal, nor are their entries into makerspaces. Educational interventions to broaden women’s and other marginalized students’ participation in makerspaces must be multipronged attending to early childhood experiences, including supportive opportunities for K-12 and early college participation, expanding definitions of making legitimizing arts and crafts, and creating immersive opportunities for women to mentor women. The narrative of who are makers, what is making, and who belongs in makerspaces must be challenged to reduce barriers and create inclusive making communities.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2023
Modified by: Julie S Linsey

  • Our research shows that university students learn a wide variety of skills and proficiencies in makerspaces.
